body:
This is by design. st.rerun raises an exception to interrupt code execution on the current thread while it starts a new one for the rerun.

Your 're-raise' of the exception should allow it to propagate, but you may want to check for a RerunException before you call your logging functions in the handling block.

Now, I'm a little confused by the fact that you're seeing that clicking the button in the decorated function is failing to trigger a rerun. Buttons should trigger a script rerun separately from the st.rerun function, and they do not use exceptions to do so. Your plain_function should actually be triggering two reruns. One on the button press and then a second one when the st.rerun statement is hit on the follow rerun.

Thank you very much for your reply. The example I provided might not have been very good. I used the `st.button` example as a quick way to replicate the error. A more realistic example is a logging decorator that wraps the main app function:

```python
@base_logger.log_errors(logger)
def app():
    ...
```

This means that all the modules used in the Streamlit app will be wrapped with that logger decorator. The main goal is to capture any errors, store them in a `.log` file, and possibly create email alerts and metrics for errors in the app. However, using `st.rerun` inside the main app function and any any sub-module raises the error I mentioned earlier.

I want to highlight that this approach was working fine with version 1.36, but it started failing in version 1.37.

I think there must be something else going on in your actual code that is not happening in the example you provided, as I am unable to repro this behavior on the latest `develop` branch. It doesn't seem like you actually ran the repro example you provided, either, since it does not run (it raises a `DuplicateWidgetID` error because both buttons have the exact same text). Therefore I had to come up with my own.

The following shows two buttons, one which runs a counter and then resets the page, and then another which does the same thing but wraps everything in a try/except block. Both buttons behave as expected and both calls to `st.rerun` cause a page rerun.

```python
import streamlit as st
# import streamlit_qs as stqs
import time

def counter():
    for x in range(3):
        st.write(x)
        time.sleep(1)
    st.rerun()


if st.button("notry"):
    counter()

if st.button("try"):
    try:
        counter()
    except Exception as exc:
        st.error(exc)
        time.sleep(1)
        raise
```

I was able to repro the error in your example please see the gif bellow:

Version 1.37:

![debug_st137](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/59281f69-6ad1-4214-9b7e-2373571f34a0)

While version 1.36 is fine:

![debug_st136](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e2f29847-7fa9-472d-a1a9-6c57dda622d0)

In addition there more people noticing this behaviour here: https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/in-version-1-37-st-rerun-fails-when-called-inside-a-try-except-block/75878

> 
> In addition there more people noticing this behaviour here: https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/in-version-1-37-st-rerun-fails-when-called-inside-a-try-except-block/75878

In the same discussion I provided a temporary workaround: https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/in-version-1-37-st-rerun-fails-when-called-inside-a-try-except-block/75878/2?u=andreasntr

This kind of reruns worked in versions previous to 1.37

I think I see what you mean... in 1.37 the script is waiting to re-run until the exception is re-raised in the try except block, while in 1.36 it re-runs right away as soon as the rerun function is called.

Do you have `runner.fastReruns` set to false perchance?

> I think I see what you mean... in 1.37 the script is waiting to re-run until the exception is re-raised in the try except block, while in 1.36 it re-runs right away as soon as the rerun function is called.
> 
> Do you have `runner.fastReruns` set to false perchance?

No runner.fastReruns is set to true

Thanks for looking into this! I perhaps have changed it based on the linter complaint:

![Screenshot 2024-07-29 at 18 07 43](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c7df0c69-ab12-4d8a-b6da-32ca068ad245)

I don't remember off the top of my head whether there was another reason for this change to be honest ðŸ¤” I will look into this and see whether there was a good reason for the change and if not, change it back!
@raethlein Cool, I think if we do change it back we should add a unit test to prevent a future similar regression.

@Asaurus1 Yep absolutely! Though I have just refreshed my mind and read a little bit about the exception types and based on the [docs](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html) "[...] programmers are encouraged to derive new exceptions from the [Exception](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#Exception) class or one of its subclasses, and not from [BaseException](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#BaseException)."  and the [Python tutorial docs](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/errors.html#tut-userexceptions) say:
> [BaseException](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#BaseException) is the common base class of all exceptions. One of its subclasses, [Exception](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#Exception), is the base class **of all the non-fatal exceptions**. Exceptions which are not subclasses of [Exception](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#Exception) are not typically handled, because they are used to indicate that the program should terminate. They include [SystemExit](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#SystemExit) which is raised by [sys.exit()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/sys.html#sys.exit) and [KeyboardInterrupt](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#KeyboardInterrupt) which is raised when a user wishes to interrupt the program.

To me this sounds like deriving from `BaseException` would not necessarily be the right thing to do, because the `ScriptControlException` is not fatal to the program itself. However, of course, the counterpoint is that this is how the library has worked until the change. What do you think about this?
I will also bring it up with the rest of the team and let them chime in.

> Exceptions which are not subclasses of Exception are not typically handled, because they are used to indicate that the program should terminate. 


Both RerunException and StopException are not "fatal". But both of them indicate that the program (i.e. the current script run) should terminate, either because we want to start another one, or because we want to stop. Just like system exit and keyboard interrupts, they do not indicate the presence of an error that the developer needs to address or handle in some way, which is what exceptions derived from Exception typically do.

We have discussed this and are going to revert the change of the Exception-type back. Together with some other bug fixes we might issue a patch release later this week.
Thanks for the analysis in this thread and the discussion, really appreciate it! And sorry for the inconvenience ðŸ™‚

## Describe your changes

Closes #9155, #9182

Unfortunately, I changed the base class of `ScriptControlException` in https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/commit/485ec8d64a1b2c6b6662ad140d99447a185d3bb2 from `BaseException` to `Exception`. This broke a bunch of user apps because `st.rerun` started to not work in `try-except` blocks anymore when `Exception` was caught. We use `BaseException` again after some discussion to avoid the exception being caught in the accidentally.

## GitHub Issue Link (if applicable)

## Testing Plan

- E2E Tests
  - Add a test to ensure that the base class won't be changed unnoticeably again in the future
